poem:
**Supermarket Blues**

In aisles where bargains once blossomed,  
profit's hushed whisper fades—  
the strike of discount hunters  
echoes through barren checkout lanes.  
Coins jingle in thinner pockets,  
branches heavy with slumped profit.  
A trolley's hollow rattle spells  
the music of a tightening belt.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Woolworths’ profit slumps as cost of living drives shoppers elsewhere Woolworths has recorded a rare slide in profit after customers grappling with rising living costs abruptly shifted some of their weekly grocery spend away from Australia’s biggest supermarket chain. The financial result, a near 21% drop in its six-month net profit to $739m, was also weighed down by industrial disruptions at Woolworths’ warehouses and an intense focus by customers searching for discounts. There is also". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
